summary: A New York Times article detailing how Jeffrey Epstein used New York City dance studios as a hunting ground to recruit young dancers for sexual exploitation, including after his 2008 conviction. The article references multiple lawsuits filed against Epstein's estate and describes patterns of recruitment and abuse.

connections.description: Epstein relied on a network of recruiters within New York City dance studios to procure aspiring performers for sexual exploitation.
Epstein sexually exploited young dancers recruited from studios, coercing them into sexual acts through promises, payments, and threats.

events.title: First dancer recruitment
events.description: A 17-year-old dancer was approached after a ballet class and asked if she wanted to give private exercise classes to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Multiple dancer recruitments
events.description: Multiple dancers were recruited in New York, one to give Epstein a massage and another to be his personal trainer.

events.title: Epstein's jail sentence
events.description: Epstein served a 13-month sentence in a Florida jail but was permitted to leave for work release 12 hours a day, six days a week.

events.title: Abuse during work release
events.description: While on work release from jail, Epstein arranged for two women recruited in New York to be flown to Florida, where he pressured them into sex.

events.title: Trip to private island
events.description: A victim flew to Epstein's private island in the Caribbean, posted about it on social media, and was subsequently threatened by Epstein.

events.title: Epstein's death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in his jail cell in Manhattan while awaiting trial on federal sex-trafficking charges.

events.title: Lawsuits filed against estate
events.description: Multiple lawsuits were filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan against Epstein's estate and eight companies, alleging they assisted in sex trafficking.

locations: Epstein's private island in the Caribbean
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein used New York City dance studios as a primary hunting ground to recruit young dancers for sexual exploitation, leveraging the insular trust within the dance community.
Epstein continued his recruitment and abuse of young women even after his 2008 conviction and during his 13-month jail sentence, using work release to arrange encounters.
Multiple lawsuits filed in 2019 allege Epstein's estate and eight associated companies served as fronts for procuring victims and paying recruiters.
The United States Attorney in Manhattan is investigating close associates of Epstein who helped feed his appetite for girls.
Epstein's activities in Manhattan apparently did not cross the radar of the NYPD's Special Victims Division at the time.
